PatientMatching.TEXT:
Record date: 2078-10-28
CARDIOLOGY
PREAKNESS HEALTHCARE CENTER
Interval History: Roger Easterling, M.D. 27 Caroll St, #734 Bluefield, ME 12111
Dear Dr. Easterling:
I had the pleasure of seeing Mr. Brian Martin in the Cardiology Service on 10/28/2078. He has a history of chest pain and was evaluated at Klickitat Valley Hospital for the same by you and, I believe, Dr. Inglis. He reportedly had an echo and a treadmill test that were unconcerning.
His episodes of chest pain are interesting. He feels a sharp pain for maybe a second or two in his chest followed by rapid palpitations associated with some jaw aching. The palpitations are of sudden onset as well as sudden offset. They were occurring up to one time per day through his hospitalization at Klickitat Valley a couple of weeks ago and now have occurred on two occasions since discharge. He is otherwise in fairly good health.
Past medical history: 1) Nonalcoholic steatotic hepatosis 2) Palpitations 3) Rotator cuff surgery in 2071
Allergies:
No known drug allergy
Medications (Confirmed):
aspirin 81 mg po daily penicillin VK 500 mg po 4 x day
Family history: Mother died at age 62 of a heart attack. He has four siblings, all in good health.
Social history: He is married with two sons, age 21 and 18, both of whom are in good health. He works as an Revenue Officer for Springfield Armory Inc in Picture Rocks, Maine.
Habits: He has never used street drugs. He does not smoke tobacco. He drinks 6 beers/alcohol per week and 2 cups of coffee per day.
Review of systems: Negative in detail as detailed on his questionnaire and confirmed during the office visit.
Physical examination:
-BP: 110/70 -Pulse: 59 BPM regular -resp. rate: 16 unlabored -Skin: without lesions or nodules. -HEENT: EOMI. PERRLA. Sclerae are anicteric. Conjunctivae noninjected. Mucous membranes moist. No oropharyngeal lesions. -Neck: carotids 2+ without bruits; jugular venous pressure <5 cm of water; thyroid without nodules; trachea midline. -Chest: lungs clear to auscultation, resonant to percussion, and symmetric in expansion. -Cardiac: regular with a normal S1/S2; no murmurs, rubs, or gallops. -Abdomen: soft, nontender, without organomegaly or other masses. -Extremities: no clubbing, cyanosis, or edema. -Neuro: reflexes were 1+; cranial nerves 2-12 were intact; motor and sensory modalities were intact in all four extremities.
EKG: 10/28/2078: Sinus bradycardia. Otherwise the tracing is within normal limits.
Assessment and plan: Mr. Martin has episodic palpitations associated with some chest discomfort. Sometimes it is difficult for patients to distinguish between palpitations and chest pain per se. It may also be that his palpitations raise his heart rate to the point where he becomes ischemic, notwithstanding the negative stress test that he had in the past.
We will request the records of the echo and the stress test so we can have them for our files here and I have asked him to complete a 30-day event recording and follow up with me after that has been completed.
I will certainly keep you informed about how things progress.
Yours truly,
Norman C. Ivers, M.D.
Norman C. Ivers, MD
Transcribed by: Nina Uresti
Signed electronically by Norman C. Ivers, MD Document Status: Final
**************************************************************************************************** Record date: 2078-12-16
CARDIOLOGY
PREAKNESS HEALTHCARE CENTER
Reason for visit:
Interval History: Roger Easterling, M.D. 27 Caroll St, #734 Bluefield, ME 12111
Dear Dr. Easterling:
We had the pleasure of seeing Brian Martin in the Cardiology Service for follow up of rapid heart action. At his last visit we gave him a 30-day loop event recorder for arrhythmia surveillance due to palpitations. Since that point he has transmitted events showing rapid atrial fibrillation up to 160 Bpm associated with chest discomfort, jaw pain and chest thumping. These episodes occur on a random basis and last up to 45 minutes. He does not identify any precipitating factors and symptoms resolve spontaneously. He denies dyspnea, PND, orthopnea, lightheadedness, pre syncope or syncope. He reportedly has had a negative stress test and echocardiogram. He is not on any medications. He has never been on Coumadin.
Past medical history: 1. Paroxysmal Atrial Fibrillation 2. Nonalcoholic steatotic hepatitis 3. Palpitations 4. Rotator cuff surgery in 2071
Changes to Allergies
NKA: No Known Allergies - reaction: [reviewed]
Medications (Confirmed):
Family history: Mother died at age 62 of a heart attack. He has four siblings, all in good health.
Social history: He is married with two sons, age 21 and 18, both of whom are in good health. He works as an Revenue Officer for Springfield Armory Inc in Picture Rocks, Maine.
Habits: He has never used street drugs. He does not smoke tobacco. He drinks 6 beers/alcohol per week and 2 cups of coffee per day.
Review of systems: Negative in detail as detailed on his questionnaire and confirmed during the office visit.
Physical examination:
-BMI: 29.3 Overweight, moderate risk -Pulse: 64 BPM regular -resp. rate: 16 unlabored -height: 68 in. -weight: 192 lbs. -General: Alert, pleasant and cooperative -Skin: Warm, dry and intact -HEENT: Normocephalic and atraumatic -Neck: Trachea is midline, no thyromegaly, no lymphadenopathy, carotid pulses are 2+ equal bilaterally without bruits. -Chest: Clear to auscultation anteriorly and posteriorly. -Cardiac: S1S2 without murmurs, rubs, gallops, thrills or heaves. PMI is at 5th ICS, MCL. JVP is at 5 cm water. -Extremities: No peripheral edema. DP/PT pulses 2+ equal and strong. -BP: 140/90
EKG: Sinus Rhythm 64 Bpm. PR Interval 134 ms, QRS 90 ms, QT/QTc 392/404 ms.
Assessment and plan: Mr. Martin is a 52-year-old male with paroxysmal atrial fibrillation. We have discussed the physiology of the electrical conduction system and the pathophysiology of atrial fibrillation. We have discussed treatment options including rate control, rhythm control or pulmonary vein isolation. We have scheduled him for nuclear stress test to R/O ischemia given his symptoms of chest discomfort and new onset of atrial fibrillation and will send him for echocardiogram to R/O structural heart disease.
We have had a long discussion regarding Cryo Ablation and if his diagnostic testing is within normal limits he would like to possibly consider this as an option for treatment. We have started him on Toprol XL 50 mg daily. If his diagnostic testing is within normal limits we will proceed initially with starting Class IC antiarrhythmic for the treatment of his atrial fibrillation. We will continue a discussion regarding Cryo Ablation and continue medical management. He has a CHAD2 Score of 0. We will therefore recommend treating with Aspirin 325 mg daily for prophylactic embolic protection and would not recommend coumadin at this time.
We will complete diagnostic testing, follow up with the results and then proceed. We have encouraged him to call with any questions, concerns, or changes in health status. Please do not hesitate to contact us with any questions in regard to his care.
Vonda Tara Ulloa, NP
The patient was seen by Dr. Ivers who reviewed the history, physical examination and relevant diagnostic test reports and determined the assessment and plan.
Norman C. Ivers, M.D.
Changes to Medications this visit
Toprol XL 50 mg po daily QTY:30 Start: 12/16/2078
Vonda T. Ulloa, NP
Norman C. Ivers, MD
Signed electronically by Vonda T. Ulloa, NP; Norman C. Ivers, MD Document Status: Final
**************************************************************************************************** Record date: 2079-01-20
CARDIOLOGY
PREAKNESS HEALTHCARE CENTER
Reason for visit: Follow up for Atrial Fibrillation and Positive Nuclear Stress Test
Interval History: January 20, 2079
Roger Easterling, M.D. 27 Caroll St, #734 Bluefield, ME 12111
Dear Dr. Easterling:
We had the pleasure of seeing Brian Martin in the Cardiology Service for follow up of atrial fibrillation to discuss findings on recent SESTA MIBI. As you know, he is a 52-year-old male with recent history of palpitations discovered to be atrial fibrillation. Episodes have been associated with chest discomfort, jaw pain and chest thumping and we therefore had him complete nuclear stress test and echocardiogram to R/O structural heart disease. He is on Toprol XL 50 mg and aspirin. SESTA MIBI completed January 5, 2079 after 11 minutes, 13 METS and 90 MPHR was positive ischemia by ECG demonstrated by 2 mm ST depressions in leads II, AVF, and V6 and 2.5 mm ST depressions in leads III and V5. Myocardial scans showed mild anteroseptal and apical ischemia with EF 66%. He had no symptoms and there were occasional VPCs and PACs. Echocardiogram was normal with exception to mildly dilated LA 40 mm.
Since his last visit he has had two additional of episodes of atrial fibrillation with complaint of rapid heart action, jaw pain and chest discomfort. The episodes lasted approximately 10 minutes and were relieved by rest. He denied lightheadedness, dizziness, pre syncope, syncope, nausea, vomiting or diaphoresis. Of note they occurred this time with exercise as opposed to at rest and they seemed more severe in nature.
Past medical history: 1. Paroxysmal Atrial Fibrillation 2. Nonalcoholic steatotic hepatitis 3. Palpitations 4. Rotator cuff surgery in 2071
Changes to Allergies
NKA: No Known Allergies - reaction: [reviewed]
Medications (Confirmed):
aspirin 81 mg po daily
Family history: Mother died at age 62 of a heart attack. He has four siblings, all in good health.
Social history: He is married with two sons, age 21 and 18, both of whom are in good health. He works as an Revenue Officer for Springfield Armory Inc in Picture Rocks, Maine.
Habits: He has never used street drugs. He does not smoke tobacco. He drinks 6 beers/alcohol per week and 2 cups of coffee per day.
Review of systems: Negative in detail as detailed on his questionnaire and confirmed during the office visit.
Physical examination:
-BMI: 28.8 Overweight, moderate risk -Pulse: 55 BPM regular -resp. rate: 16-18 unlabored -height: 68 in. -weight: 189 lbs. -General: Alert, pleasant and cooperative -Skin: Warm, dry and intact -HEENT: Normocephalic and atraumatic -Neck: Trachea is midline, no thyromegaly, no lymphadenopathy, carotid pulses are 2+ equal bilaterally without bruits. -Cardiac: S1S2 without murmurs, rubs, gallops, thrills or heaves. PMI is at 5th ICS, MCL. JVP is at 5 cm water. -Abdomen: soft, nontender, without organomegaly or other masses. -Extremities: No peripheral edema. DP/PT pulses 2+ equal and strong. -BP: 145/90
EKG: Sinus Bradycardia 55 Bpm, PR Interval 142 ms, QRS 92 ms, and QT/QTc 428/409 ms.
Selected recent labs:
Metabolic Date NA K CL CO2 BUN CRE GLU CA 01/20/79 136 4.3 99 28.0 13 1.0 241 9.4
Liver and Pancreatic Enzymes Date ALB TP ALKP TBILI ALT/SGPT AST/SGOT 01/20/79 4.6 8.2 81 0.8 46 32
Lipid/Thyroid Date TSH 01/20/79 2.11
Hematology Date HCT RBC WBC PLT 01/20/79 48.8 5.51 6.4 269
Coagulation Date PT PT-INR 01/20/79 12.0 1.0
Urinalysis Date UA-COLOR UA-APP UA-GLUC UA-BILI UA-SPGR UA-BLD UA-PH UA-PROT UA-UROBI UA-NIT 01/20/79 Yellow Clear 3+ NEGATIVE 1.023 NEGATIVE 6.0 NEGATIVE NEGATIVE NEGATIVE
24 hr Urine Date CRE 01/20/79 1.0
other Date GLOB HGB MCV MCH MCHC RDW UA-KET UA-WBC 01/20/79 3.6 16.8 89 30.4 34.3 12.9 NEGATIVE NEGATIVE
Other Data: 1. SESTA-MIBI January 5, 2079. Conclusions: 11min, 13 METS, peak HR 151 90% MPHR. Excellent exercise capacity. ECG is positive for ischemia, myocardial perfusion scans show mild anteroseptal and apical ischemia. LVEF 66%.
2. Echocardiogram December 23, 2078. Conclusions: No MVP. LA dilated 40 mm. Aortic valve is tricuspid, no AI. LV cavity size and systolic function is within normal limits without evidence of segmental wall motion abnormalities and EF 76%. Right atrial dilatation. Normal RV. LA 40 mm, LVIDd 50 mm, LVIDs 29 mm, PWT 10 mm, IVS 10 mm and LVEF 76%.
Assessment and plan: Mr. Martin is a 52-year-old male with paroxysmal atrial fibrillation and ischemia noted on recent SESTA MIBI. We have discussed the findings and have recommended proceeding with cardiac catheterization with potential coronary intervention. We have reviewed pre procedural expectations and procedural risk including femoral vascular complications, cardiac perforation, renal complications, stroke, heart attack, and death. He understands and has agreed to proceed. We have also discussed treatment options for atrial fibrillation. He continues to be interested in CRYO Ablation. We have had a long discussion in this regard. We will have to start medication therapy first and then proceed accordingly. His medication options are now limited due to ischemia. Sotalol is the best option at this time.
We have spoken to Dr. Nagle who has agreed to complete his catheterization on January 24, 2079. If the dye load is minimal we may decide to complete in patient Sotalol load. We will assess after his angiogram. We have completed pre procedure blood work, CXR and urinalysis.
We have encouraged him to call with any questions, concerns or changes in health status. Please do not hesitate to contact us with any questions in regard to his care.
Vonda Tara Ulloa, NP
The patient was seen by Dr. Ivers who reviewed the history, physical examination and relevant diagnostic test reports and determined the assessment and plan.
Norman C. Ivers, M.D.
Changes to Medications this visit
Toprol XL 50 mg po daily QTY:30 Start: 12/16/2078
Vonda T. Ulloa, NP
Norman C. Ivers, MD
Signed electronically by Vonda T. Ulloa, NP; Norman C. Ivers, MD Document Status: Final
